Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
Article Title: A Philosophical History of the Society for Phenomenology and Existential Philosophy?
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jspecphil.26.2.issue-2
Date: 4 1, 2012
Abstract: Is SPEP the city of God? This would be going too far. Not even the theological turn in French Phenomenology would make this claim. Dick Howard already threw in a troubling question: “diversification that perhaps gives more breadth than depth?” he asked. And there are plenty more troubling questions. SPEP is now a big operation. It has committees and subcommittees, multiple simultaneous sessions, blind review. All these developments are signs, perhaps inevitable ones, of its success, but all have familiar downsides: bureaucratization, diversification for its own sake, what Habermas would call Unübersichtlichkeit. This is what happens when outsiders become insiders, the antis become their own sort of establishment. You can't blame some of us for feeling nostalgic for our long-lost innocence, even though we all know—you don't have to be a philosopher of history to know this—that we can't go there. History has rendered a judgment, but Dick Howard said, “Historywilljudge.” That's one problem with history: It's always rendering judgments, but they are never final. You'd have to be at the end of history for that, and despite the claim of some philosophers, we aren't there yet. The slaughter bench of history looks very different today from the early 1960s, but it's still in some ways a slaughter bench. So how will the SPEP of the early twenty-first century look to the philosopher-historians of 2061—or is it 2062?
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/jspecphil.26.2.0102 journal-article-10.5325_jspecphil.26.2.0102.xml

Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
Article Title: American Continental Philosophy in the Making:
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jspecphil.26.2.issue-2
Date: 4 1, 2012
Abstract: And so, although we certainly shared their concern for the neglected and misunderstood topics we read about in Kierkegaard, Dilthey, Jaspers, Sartre, Husserl, and Nietzsche, none of their accounts of these matters seemed fully responsive to their experiential sense. All of these thinkers seemed, to me at least, to partially betray their own best insights by how they presented them. Dilthey, for instance, leaves everything that stands in the way of his philosophical success in place. In the end, having self-identified as an epistemologist of the “other” sciences—that is, someone interested in a “second” method for understanding unobservable “inner” life instead of the standard method for explaining observable “outer” nature—he is ultimately able to do no better that assure us that even if Verstehenwon't give us “objectivity” in the usual sense, it can at least give us what he weakly calls a “subjectively objective” analogue. 10
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/jspecphil.26.2.0108 journal-article-10.5325_jspecphil.26.2.0108.xml

Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
Article Title: The Plight of Ethics
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jspecphil.26.2.issue-2
Date: 4 1, 2012
Abstract: Without sovereignty and without ownership, we are responsible for what we cannot and do not control, for our unconscious fears and desires and their effects on others. The fragile hope is that by acknowledging the death drive within ourselves, we can begin to prevent killing and never give up trying to find ways to abolish death penalties in all their forms. The death drive is not the Kantian notion of death as the great equalizer but, rather, the tension in life itself, both destructive and creative, always conjoined with both pleasure and pain, joy and sorrow, and the ambiguities of life that not only exceed but also expose the fantasy of death as an absolute end point or final resting place. Far from the Perpetual Peace of the Dutch innkeeper's sign, with which Kant ironically opens his essay, the death drive is the force that fuels the fantasy of the end of life as everlasting peace.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/jspecphil.26.2.0118 journal-article-10.5325_jspecphil.26.2.0118.xml

Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
Article Title: Phenomenology
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jspecphil.26.2.issue-2
Date: 4 1, 2012
Abstract: Second, this way of characterizing Heidegger is similar to what I would offer, still with sharp differences, regarding Jacques Derrida. I find Derrida's project governed from beginning to end by the nonability of phenomenology (or of any other intellectual undertaking) to reachan ultimate of origin. Placing his 1953–54mémoireand two of his books, one large,De la grammatologie(1967; trans. Baltimore, 1974), and one small,Positions(1972; trans. Chicago, 1981), together with the fact that the transformation of the field of philosophic concern was worked entirely in the play of wordings, in the play ofmeaning differentiation and collusion, exhibits the four characteristics I have proposed. For Derrida regularly showed—afterOn GrammatologyandPositions, usually without saying so—how the absolute nonfeasibility of finding origins would undermine any assertion of canonic status and stability for conceptualities. Instead, the very meaningfulness of canonic terminology (a) demanded a freer play of meaning for understanding any such purported paradigmatic sense, (b) showed the nonvalidity of any absolute priority-granting properness to their usage, and (c) exhibited instead their fundamentalrelativity. No other person in phenomenology came close to the effectiveness Derrida showed in this, and very few, so far as I know, recognize the phenomenology-necessitated character of these efforts.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/jspecphil.26.2.0222 journal-article-10.5325_jspecphil.26.2.0222.xml

Date: 4 1, 2012
Abstract: No doubt the rise of religion has not only posed a particular dilemma for critical theory but also provided a curious place to end this reflection. Having started my career doing philosophy of religion it is somewhat surprising to meet religion again as I turn to what surely must be at least a later phase of my career. I am reminded of Antonio's line from the Italian film C'eravamo Tanto Amati, translated asWe All Loved Each Other So Much: “We thought we could change the world, but the world changed us.” “Philosophers only interpret the world, the point is to change it,” so said Marx. But in a curious way those who would change the world are changed by it.

Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
Article Title: French Poststructuralism
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jspecphil.26.2.issue-2
Date: 4 1, 2012
Abstract: Three years later in the next edition of selected SPEP papers the editors, Ronald Bruzina and Bruce Wilshire, noted an article by David Allison, “Structuralism Revisited: Levi Straus and Diachrony.” They suggested that to understand it the reader would need to draw from knowledge of Heidegger, Derrida, Deleuze, and Ricoeur. They also noted a paper by Matthieu Casalis, “Hermeneutics, Death of God, and Dissolution of the Subject: A Phenomenological Appraisal,” that indicates a growing challenge to what we could call a strong tendency toward totalization in some aspect of phenomenological thought, as well as the high stakes that are at issue. Interest in Marxist thought and critical theory as well as in social science also intensified during the 1970s, and by the end of the decade papers in these areas were common, while papers also emerged on politics and political action. The currents crossing the phenomenological mainstream were now strong and, for some members, challenging in a disconcerting way that most people in SPEP in the 1960s could not have imagined. Many people who were deeply impacted by the civil rights struggle (in spite of the absence in SPEP of a significant presence of people of color), the Vietnam War protests, and the growing awareness of colonialism and gender inequality were taking philosophy in the context of phenomenology and existentialism out of the modern transcendental and metaphysical domain, some by direct challenges to interpretations of canonical texts and others by setting new directions that arose out of contemporary problems and concern for social justice. Social-historical factors and careful analyses of narrative forms began to replace epistemology as leading interests, and these factors and forms often replaced metaphysical foundations in their work. “Humanism” became increasingly a problem rather than an unquestioned term concerning human life and the context of its interpretation.4

Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
Article Title: Philosophy of Technology
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jspecphil.26.2.issue-2
Date: 4 1, 2012
Abstract: These are nano-, bio-, info-, and cognotechnologies. For reasons I will clarify, I add robo- and imaging technologies to this list. But before some specific examples, take note of how these new technologies differfrom the mega-, mechanical, industrial technologies called “modern” by Heidegger. In each case the target entities with which these technologies intervene are extrememicrophenomena. Nanotechnologies manipulate at the atomic and molecular levels, trapping atoms, deflecting photons; biotechnologies operate at the genetic level, DNA, RNA, proteins; cognotechnologies, also employing imaging, depict neurotransmissions and the like. I shall later address the info-, robo-, and imaging technologies. At the end of the Cold War, physics, while interested in subatomic particles and wedded to monster colliders to investigate these phenomena, was about to lose its biggest instrument, the supercollider, which was canceled in 1994, in part because it was not deemed so important. The subsequent emergence of biology, also wed to microphenomena, could use much smaller instruments.

Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
Article Title: Ethics and Religion in Continental Philosophy
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jspecphil.26.2.issue-2
Date: 4 1, 2012
Abstract: It is the emphasis on transcendence that provides the segue from ethics to religion. It is in the ethical relation that God “comes to mind.” Here again, Levinas is in important respects a Kantian. Kant insists that “on its own behalf morality in no way needs religion,” but he adds that it “inevitably leads to religion.” Of course, the self-sufficiency of ethics does not for Levinas rest on pure practical reason, nor does it lead to religion as “the idea of a mighty moral lawgiver outside the human being, in whose will the final end (of the creation of the world) is what can and at the same [time] ought to be the final human end.”16 But it is clear that for Levinas ethics does not depend on religion in this sense and that it does lead to religion in his own sense of the term.17

Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
Article Title: Is a Hermeneutic Phenomenology Wide Enough? A Ricoeurian Reply to Janicaud's
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: jspecphil.28.3.issue-3
Date: 7 1, 2014
Author(s): Davidson Scott
Abstract: First, hermeneutics rejects the scientific ideal of phenomenology. Husserl conceives phenomenology in foundational terms as a first philosophy whose role is to provide a metaphysical grounding or an Archimedean point for scientific knowledge. But hermeneutics challenges the foundational enterprise altogether. The search for foundations, on this view, is forgetful of its own origins within a more encompassing context of relations. Thought can never establish itself at the beginning or end point; instead it is always situated in medias res, that is, in the midst of a conversation or dialogue that has already begun.12

Journal Title: Philosophy & Rhetoric
Article Title: Recovering Hyperbole:
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: philrhet.45.4.issue-4
Date: 12 1, 2012
Abstract: Stretching verbato its breaking point, he dramatically attempts to communicate and re-present an extraordinaryresthrough the disorienting and performative twists and turns of hyperbolicincrementumandcongeries. In a representative example, he writes: Amid this teeming sea of paradoxical complexities and discursive amalgamations, Taylor's excessive thought regarding “the Holy” that is “irreducibly ex-orbitant” and interrupts the “circulation of knowledge” reveals the use of hyperbole at work as he navigates across an ambiguous theo-philosophical topography. Incrementally augmenting, accumulating, and building toward this unrealizable term, he “throws beyond” incongruities in order to push toward the apprehension that “the Holy” is “that which cannot be conceived.” He is making the attempt to communicate the inconceivable through his language of excess and exaggeration, which is the only way he could make the attempt effectively, and the insight gleaned from his work is that the disorienting movement of theology and a/theology, beyond the end of theology, is equally and inevitably an impossible possibility.The trace of the fugitive gods is the nonabsent absence of the Holy. This trace is a different trace, the trace of difference itself, which can never be expressed directly, revealed totally, or known completely. It is ever elusive, evasive, excessive. Irreducibly ex-orbitant, the Holy eternally returns to interrupt the circulation of knowledge and to disrupt every form of reciprocal exchange. To hear the “inhuman,” “anonymous,” “uncanny” murmur of the Holy is to become open to that which cannot be conceived, grasped, mastered, or controlled. (1990, 119)

Journal Title: Philosophy & Rhetoric
Article Title: “Reading the Past against the Grain: The Shape of Memory Studies.”
Publisher: University of Chicago Press
Issue: philrhet.46.2.issue-2
Date: 4 1, 1998
Abstract: In his foreword to Ricoeur's From Text to Action, Richard Kearney asserts that “Ricoeur's work, from beginning to end, was fueled by an ontology of action” (2007, ix). Ricoeur combines his interest in action with questions of memory in the magisterialMemory, History, Forgetting(2004), in which he systematically explores the phenomenological experience—and to a lesser extent, the ethical implications—of the three central terms. However, because this work focuses more on phenomenology than the public implications of a text, other works by Ricoeur are better suited to redeployment in critical analysis. This is not to say that Ricoeur ignores important themes inMemory, History, Forgetting. For instance, he uses the evocative phrase “historian-citizen” in order to denote the public responsibility demanded by certain narratives or representations of the past (2004, 259). Unfortunately, however, Ricoeur moves quickly beyond this promising concept without fully developing it. Thus, the concepts fromTime and Narrativeand, to a lesser extent,From Text to Action, provide a more congenial point of departure for the agential spiral.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/philrhet.46.2.0182 journal-article-10.5325_philrhet.46.2.0182.xml

Journal Title: Shaw
Article Title: Dilemmas and Delusions
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: shaw.34.1.issue-1
Date: 10 1, 2014
Author(s): Wixson Christopher
Abstract: Along the same lines, in the preface to Man and Superman, he draws a distinction between two states of corporeal infirmity. The first, what he calls “the true joy of life,” results from “the being used for a purpose recognized by yourself as a mighty one; the being thoroughly worn out before you are thrown on the scrap heap, the being a force of nature.” The second is engendered by a failure of will and perspective, producing “a feverish selfish little clod of ailments and grievances, complaining that the world will not devote itself to making you happy.” Scholars and biographers have taken both views of Shaw. Countless testimonies of friends and acquaintances as well as innumerable pronouncements by GBS himself laud the extraordinary vibrancy of the “active young revolutionist” following his typical schedule of prolific writing and speech giving.22 At the same time, Shaw's private diaries are replete with meticulous physiological self-examination, documenting his crippling headaches as well as myriad illnesses, injuries, changes in weight and appetite, and suspected symptoms. Robert Brustein attributes “a kind of Swiftian disgust at the human body and its functions” to the playwright, while Sally Peters pathologizes his interest in health, arguing its origin in latent psychosis, specifically an obsessive fear of contagion.23 His commitment to vegetarianism, teetotalism, and Jaegerism, she argues, was founded as much upon hygienic paranoia as moral principle: “Fueled by a “desperate revulsion from body and biology[,] … Shaw's was an ever-lasting defense against dirt, poison, and contamination[,] whatever symbolized to him the form-destroying potencies of existence.”24 In any case, the vexed body, on its way to evolutionary elimination, assiduously preoccupied Shaw, and matters of personal and public wellness remained an idée fixe until the end of his life.25
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/shaw.34.1.0001 journal-article-10.5325_shaw.34.1.0001.xml

Journal Title: Shaw
Article Title: Bernard Shaw and Paul Ricoeur
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: shaw.34.1.issue-1
Date: 10 1, 2014
Author(s): Einsohn Howard Ira
Abstract: We can begin filling in the specifics of this answer by considering another statement Shaw's Lilith makes at the end of Back to Methuselah. “From the moment I … lose hope and faith in [humankind],” says the Life Force incarnate, “they are doomed…. I may not spare them forever.” This cautionary admonition is instructive not just because it declares that the jury is still out with respect to the race's fate. It is also revelatory in the sense that it gives us a privileged insight into the quintessential being of the man behind the work by way of the implicit homology it provides. The critical point is this: if for Shaw, the cosmic dramatist, “hope and faith” are efficacious in the divine sphere in deferring the species' demise, they are for Shaw, the everyday person, equally efficacious in the earthly sphere. The analogy works as follows. Lilith has not yet given up completely on humans in their present stage of development because she retains hope and faith in their capacity to change for the better. In a similar way, Shaw the individual does not give up completely on Lilith's stiff-necked people for precisely the same reason. He carries within him the unshakable belief that, despite all appearances to the contrary, humans have the permanent capability to modify their behavior in a manner that meets the Jesusian standard Lilith ordains: ever more abundant life on a just and peaceful planet. Whether they will realize this competency in action, no one can say with certainty, not even the goddess herself, for she too lacks the perspective of eternity. But this irreducible metaphysical possibility is all the breathing space Shaw needs to maintain his equilibrium, his wellness, in a world wildly out of kilter.28
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/shaw.34.1.0133 journal-article-10.5325_shaw.34.1.0133.xml

Journal Title: Utopian Studies
Article Title: The Rhetorical Function of Utopia:
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: utopianstudies.23.1.issue-1
Date: 4 1, 2012
Abstract: An obvious criticism of Burke's idea of rhetorical transcendence is that it is utopian in the unrealistic sense. It seems so abstract in its focus on generalized terminology and images that it may have no possible concrete object. Burke realized this utopian quality reminiscent of the lack of actualized topos in More's utopian “no-place.” As rhetorician James Zappen explains, “These acts of pure persuasion are devoid of partisan advantage-seeking but also devoid of persuasive purpose. As such, they might not even exist.” The important thing to take away from Burke's ramblings, though, is the humanistic sense that the search for perfection is inherent in human nature and that understanding this utopian impulse can only help us to live and to seek happiness in a world of competing power and advantage: “Let us observe, all about us, forever goading us, though it be in fragments, the motive that attains its ultimate identification in the thought, not of the universal holocaust, but of the universal order…. [E]ach kind strives toward the perfection of its kind, and so toward the kind next above it, while the strivings of the entire series head in God as the beloved cynosure and ninecure, the end of all desire.”35 By36 GodBurke means an ultimate ideal transcending all other symbols and fulfilling all desire—the kind of nirvana that would eliminate the need for further utopia-making altogether. This, of course, is not achievable in the course of history, but the mythic experience of it would activate a downward movement in the process, bringing the transcendent ideals back into the pragmatic world of discourse and human affairs. This would be the function of utopia in Burkean terms, and it would result in a habit of mind that would amount to a large-scale educational scheme—dare I say, the education of desires. If the young were informed of the dialectical-rhetorical process of transcendence from the beginning, ~
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/utopianstudies.23.1.0113 journal-article-10.5325_utopianstudies.23.1.0113.xml

Journal Title: Utopian Studies
Article Title: The Meta-Utopian Metatext:
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: utopianstudies.23.2.issue-2
Date: 10 1, 2012
Abstract: Leopold Bloom, in Ulysses, expansively describes the Utopian as affording “no known method from the known to the unknown.” Utopia is a place that is impossible to arrive at by any known route, in that it is not really a place at all. It is therefore essential that, in order to reach Utopia, one takes an unknown and unknowable route, a path determined by its indeterminacy, a passage that deconstructs its own rationalistic epistemological foundations. It is only in its paradoxical nature that such a route, beyond sense (which forbids entry into the unreal), might discover the reality of that unreality. For, in the end, despite its fantastical absurdities—its self-conscious nowhereness—Joyce's Dublin, like Butler's Erewhon, is the opposite of nowhere: it is somewhere. It is by inscribing the material (the somewhere) within the dream (the nowhere) that the dream might be sustained; and it is also by inscribing the dream within the real that material existence can continue.166
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/utopianstudies.23.2.0472 journal-article-10.5325_utopianstudies.23.2.0472.xml

Journal Title: Utopian Studies
Article Title: The Problematic of Architecture and Utopia
Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
Issue: utopianstudies.25.1.issue-1
Date: 4 1, 2014
Abstract: The crossroads of the end of Utopia (apparently ensured by the fall of the Berlin Wall and Soviet Russia), the end of the world (apparently easier to imagine than an alternative to capitalism), and capitalism itself (which is apparently eternal) seems an apt place to turn toward the problem of degenerate Utopia and the city, which, after all, pretty much amount to the same thing in our time. Louis Marin's proposition is that “a degenerate utopia is ideology changed into the form of a myth.” Arguably, one such myth is capitalism. Another might be modernity or modernism, and a third could be the inevitability of the contemporary city as the concretization of capitalist realism. However, the cities that most of us inhabit could conceivably be construed as Utopias by neoliberals, as constituting the best of all possible worlds for the spread of free markets, or equally so by anti-utopians, who might see in the modern city Utopia realized, that is, dystopia. In any event, and whatever one's preconceived notion of Utopia might be, the contemporary city stands primarily as confirmation “of the impotence of corporate capital to generate a socially cohesive environment.”29 As such, it is also arguably no Utopia, which persists as an open project to be imagined and realized, sometime and somewhere in the future, in the footsteps of present efforts to define Utopia for architecture and the city and to establish its spaces.30
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/utopianstudies.25.1.0001 journal-article-10.5325_utopianstudies.25.1.0001.xml

Journal Title: Science Fiction Studies
Article Title: “Mr. Bennett and Mrs. Brown.”
Publisher: Harcourt Brace
Issue: sciefictstud.41.issue-3
Date: 11 1, 1950
Abstract: R.A. Lafferty's reputation for rollicking humor and poetic verve, as demonstrated in such stories as “Narrow Valley” (1966) and “Slow Tuesday Night” (1965) belies the considerable theoretical and narratological complexity of his entire body of work. This article draws on the vocabulary developed by Paul Ricoeur in Interpretation Theory(1966) andTime and Narrative(1983–85) to explore Lafferty's process of world creation in light of his startling 1979 announcement that the cognitive world of humanity had come to an end. Thus, in this post-conscious state, it was left to science fiction to develop potential replacements. In his writings Lafferty seeks not only to project new worlds but also to reconstruct the world-building capacity in others, enabling readers and writers alike to collaborate toward a future for humanity.
Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5621/sciefictstud.41.3.0543 journal-article-10.5621_sciefictstud.41.3.0543.xml
